titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Civil War Manuscripts Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:16

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Civil War Manuscripts Collection was created to give the researcher more direct access to small and fragmentary collections of material on the subject of the Civil War in the United States, 1861-1865. It is an intentionally assembled collection of diaries, correspondence, photographs, printed material, and ephemera primarily documenting military events and daily camp life, as well as family life on the home front and civilian activities. Many Connecticut regiments are represented throughout the collection.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Further additions to this collection will meet departmental standards for additions to artificial collections and thus not amount to more than .25 linear feet of material or contain material in smaller quantities which warrant collection level status due to individual or subject content. Additions will include material generated during the Civil War period, 1861-1865, or the reminiscences, remembrances and recollections of individuals who were a party to events relating to the war.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Civil War Manuscripts Collection (MS 619). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Civil War Manuscripts Collection was created to give the researcher more direct access to small and fragmentary collections of material on the subject of the Civil War in the United States, 1861-1865. It is an intentionally assembled collection of diaries, correspondence, photographs, printed material, and ephemera primarily documenting military events and daily camp life, as well as family life on the home front and civilian activities. Many Connecticut regiments are represented throughout the collection.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Further additions to this collection will meet departmental standards for additions to artificial collections and thus not amount to more than .25 linear feet of material or contain material in smaller quantities which warrant collection level status due to individual or subject content. Additions will include material generated during the Civil War period, 1861-1865, or the reminiscences, remembrances and recollections of individuals who were a party to events relating to the war.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series: I. Civil War collections, 1836-1960. II. Civil War manuscripts, 1861-1902.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged alphabetically be personal name, family name, or subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Civil War collections, consists of materials centered around or collected by a specific person or family, primarily in the form of copious correspondence and diaries. Battles and Leaders of the Civil War , a six volume work of letters, documents, and photographs, is included in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence (originals and typed copies), 1862-1865, printed materials, photographs, and memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of seven typed manuscripts signed, autograph manuscript signed and articles on various Civil War battles.

did.unittitle: Battles and Leaders of the Civil War , edited by Robert Underwood Johnson and Clarence Clough Buel of Century Magazine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This work was extended from four to six volumes by the insertion of three hundred portraits and one hundred autograph letters and documents. Letters and documents include the correspondent's name, the type of document, the date of the document and the page number within the volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of 109 items. 52 autograph letters signed from Hiram Blaisdell to his wife, Betsy, regarding his military life and services as a private in Battery A, 3rd New York Artillery; also 49 autograph letters signed from Betsy to Hiram concerning conditions at home [Martville, Cayuga County, New York]; also 8 autograph letters signed from various other members of the Blaisdell family, including William and Melino Blaisdell (Hiram's brothers), Celenda Hancock (Betsy's aunt), Lydia T. Beebe (Hiram's aunt), Roxanna Blaisdell (Hiram's sister), and Milo D. Eldridge (relation unknown).

Hiram Blaisdell entered the 3rd New York Artillery at Auburn, New York, in September 1864; a month later he was sent to New Bern, North Carolina, where he remained almost the whole of his one year term of enlistment. An unusually homesick soldier, Hiram filled his letters with poignant regrets that he could not be at his wife's side and with much sober advice on how she was to conduct their farm during his absence. Aside from complaining of the hardships and dullness of camp life, Hiram made few observations on the war, except to anticipate a rapid peace and his return home. He does, however, give some news as to the number of rebels deserting to the Union lines.

The dull routine of camp life is broken twice--in February (1865), Hiram went on a raid and the following month (March) he participated in the hotly contested battle at Kinston, North Carolina. [Note: he gives a very good description of the effectiveness of artillery against the Confederates.] Shortly after the Battle of Kinston, Hiram succumbs to diarrhea and spends the rest of his enlistment in the LeNoir General Hospital.

Betsy's letters give a very detailed picture of life for those back home in Martville, Cayuga County, New York. She describes the hardships and loneliness of a childless wife on an isolated farm; the terrible snowstorms of upstate New York; the lack of funds and difficulty of bringing in crops; lack of help from neighbors, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arthur B. Carpenter served as a sergeant and later as an officer in the Union Army, 19th Infantry Regiment during the Civil War. The letters, mainly to his parents in Monson, Massachusetts, give war news, battle descriptions, comments on army life and politics, camp routine, civilians with whom he came in contact, military leaders, politics, religion, Negro emancipation, and details of the contemporary scene, as well as descriptions of the countryside through which he passed.

did.unittitle: Arrival at Indianapolis, starting in business and foreboding of war
Engraving of North Western Christian University on letter; impressions of Hoosiers; local reactions toward Civil War

Establishment of National Cemetery by General G. H. Thomas; problems of supply; skirmish on Tunnel Hill, Tennessee; Battle of Resaca, Georgia; account of action at Kennesaw Mountain, Georgia
March on and occupation of Atlanta, Georgia; fighting along railroads and in trenches; descriptions of Confederate fortifications; notes on Sherman's drive through the South
Routine and problems of recruiting officers; promotion to captain by Brevet; signature of Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton; comments on Copperheads and War with Mexico

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of 4 manuscript record books of Company E of the 9th Connecticut Infantry.

did.unittitle: Dana, Charles A. (1819-1897): Recollections of the Civil War; with the leaders at Washington and in the field in the sixties ; by Charles Anderson Dana, New York: D. Appleton and Company, 1898, xiii, 296 p. front. (port) 21 1/2 cm. Bound in are 12 autograph letters and numerous engraved portraits of prominent Americans.
Boutwell, George Sewel (1818-1905). Letter signed to Isaac S. Stewart [Special Treasury Agent] approving his request for a thirty day leave of absence. 1 page, Washington, DC, facing p. 12.

Dana, Charles Anderson (1819-1897). Autograph letter signed to Edwin Denison Morgan supporting Merrill Foote's request for a commission as a second lieutenant "in one of the new [NY] regiments of volunteers." At time of writing Foote was a member of Company D, 51st NY Regiment. 2 pages, New York City, following title page.
Fremont, John Charles (1813-1890). Autograph letter signed to an unidentified correspondent requesting his Washington, DC address. 1 page, New York City, facing page 7.

Hammond, William Alexander (1828-1900). Autograph letter signed to Messrs. Bullock and Crenshaw (Philadelphia druggists) ordering "100 Crusts of Vaccine Virus." 1 page, Washington, DC, facing page 74.
Hazen, William Babcock (1830-1887). Signature cut from letter. No place, facing p. 122.

Hovey, Alvin Peterson (1821-1891). Autograph letter signed to John Collett acknowledging receipt of Collett's "annual report of Indiana Statistics and Geology." 1 page, folio, Mt. Vernon, Indiana, facing p. 216.
Janes, Paul. Letter signed to "Mr. Hazeltine" enclosing a copy of George W. Ross's speech before the Canadian Club of New York. 1 page, folio, New York City, facing p. 262.

King, John Lyle. Autograph letter signed (incomplete) to John Alexander Logan recommending William H. Burkhart for a federal judgeship in the Eastern District of Texas. Note by Logan on verso. 1 page, folio, no place, facing p. 96.

Mayer, Brantz (1809-1879). Autograph letter signed to unidentified general promising to send a private report relative to the transfer of army headquarters from Omaha to Council Bluffs, Iowa. 1 page, Lincoln, Nebraska, facing p. 67.
Stanton, Edwin McMasters (1814-1869). Signature cut from letter, no place, facing p. 22.
Welles, Gideon (1802-1878). Autograph letter signed to Andrew Johnson requesting his signature for the naval commission of William L. Low. 1 page, Washington, DC, facing p. 171.

Wilson, James Harrison (1837-1925). Autograph letter signed to Messrs. Winslow and Wilson of New York City complaining about the fact that some of his personal mail was mistakenly sent to the wrong party. 1 page, St. Louis, Missouri, facing p. 62.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of original, typed and photostatic copies of diary from time in Andersonville Military Prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John O. Gay was a soldier from Weymouth, Massachusetts, who volunteered for service around June 1864. His letters to his family during the last year of the war were mostly written from Washington, DC, where he was stationed after November 1864. While not very informative about the war, they convey the character of a religious man with strong family feeling who misses his home and family intensely. There are a few comments on Lincoln's assassination in the letters of April 1865, and some details, in passing, on the day to day life of a soldier. Two letters from his wife, Susan, are also in the collection.

did.unittitle: Letters written from Fort Ethan Allen
Letters written from the "Potomac River," and from Forts Craig and Reynolds in Washington, DC
Letters written from Fort Reynolds in Washington, DC

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Herrick Gile was a captain in Grant's Army of Tennessee, and aide-de-camp to General James B. McPherson. He participated in the Battles of Vicksburg and Chattanooga, and Sherman's March through Georgia and the March to the Sea. His letters often contain vivid descriptions of army life and some excellent accounts of battles. In addition to the letters, there is a family genealogy, some photographs, and some war memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of letters, 1861 Nov 29-1864 Mar 9, from Harrison Ingalls of South Westerlo, Albany County, New York, to members of his family while serving with the 91st New York Volunteers in Florida and Louisiana. There are also a series of letters, 1861 Apr 6-1865 Dec 2, from various family members in Michigan, Indiana, and New York to Truman Ingalls (1804-1867), Harrison's father, including letters from other family members serving in the war. These family letters contain many comments and details on war matters, local and family affairs, and domestic economy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of Colonel Edward Christopher James consist chiefly of 107 letters written during the period August 22, 1861, to August 5, 1863, while he was with the 106th Volunteers of New York. The letters are addressed to his mother, Lucia Ripley James (1819-1901), and to his father, Amaziah Bailey James (1812-1883), in Ogdensburg, New York. The remainder of the collection includes memorabilia and photographs of family and prominent Civil War figures, many of which were taken by M. S. Brady.

Colonel James served as acting-assistant adjutant-general of the engineer brigade of the New York 50th Volunteers during the winter of 1861-1862 and during the Peninsular Campaign (1862) was aide-de-camp on the staff of General Daniel P. Woodbury, commanding the engineering brigade in the Army of the Potomac. James made an extremely rapid rise in rank from adjutant in 1861 at the age of 20 to the rank of colonel in 1862 at the age of 21. Many of the letters deal with the trials and tribulations of command for so young an officer. Along with reflections on home, honor, and duty, the letters provide a valuable insight into Union Army life as experienced by a most impressionable young man.

did.unittitle: Volunteer enlistment and Army commissions, 5 large documents
Printed biographical sketch of E. C. James, 5 pages
Printed history of Ogdensburg, New York, during the Civil War, p. 112-167

Typescript: description of papers and identification of persons mentioned in the letters, by Mrs. Philip Gray. 4 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loose photographs. Small carte-de-visite size. 53 items. Mostly of Civil War leaders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album of 50 small photographs, mostly Civil War leaders, including duplicates of those in folder 7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of letters, diaries, documents, printed material, clippings, and photographs regarding Dr. Jarvis's service during the war and with the Connecticut Infantry, 7th Regiment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of letters from Lusk to members of his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of letters from Norman to his wife and some miscellaneous items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence, diaries, and other papers, 1862-1866, relating primarily to Paddock's duties as quartermaster with the 1st Regiment of the Connecticut Artillery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Spencer Parmelee was the son of Spencer Thomas Parmelee, a New Haven merchant and president of the Fair Haven and Westville Horse Railroad, which was the first street railroad in New Haven. He entered the service as a member of Company B of the 1st Connecticut Cavalry on September 8, 1862, in Bridgeport, Connecticut, and was stationed at Fort Trumbull in New London, Connecticut, for several weeks before being sent to the Baltimore and Washington, DC, areas. He served as an orderly for General Henry S. Briggs of the Army of the Potomac for some time and lost his right hand at the Battle of Sayler's Creek, Virginia.

The correspondence consists of approximately 180 letters between Parmelee and members of his family in New Haven. Much of this correspondence is fairly routine, describing the details of camp and army life and family and social news from home. It would appear from the correspondence that Parmelee did not see much battle action himself, although there is some information on the death of his brother Lewis at Antietam. There is also some correspondence from others who were not members of the family, notably, a few letters from General Briggs.

did.unittitle: Commission and discharge papers, orders, reports, printed material, and other papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous papers collected by Seymour while a member of the Christian Commission in Richmond, Virginia. Eleven reports by field commanders on an engagement in the defense of Richmond between June 28 and July 2, 1862, make up half of the papers. Also included are correspondence and other papers of General John H. Winder relating to his office as provost marshal and commander of the Northern prisons in Richmond. In addition, scattered items of correspondence and official documents from departments of the Confederate States in Richmond, 1862-1865, to and from Jefferson Davis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William H. Warren was a soldier in the 17th Regiment, Connecticut Infantry Volunteers. The regiment was organized at Bridgeport, Fairfield County, Connecticut, and was mustered on August 28, 1862. The regiment was mustered out on July 19, 1865, at Hilton Head, Beaufort County, South Carolina.

did.unittitle: "William H. Warren's Experience as a Prisoner of War. Captured at Gettysburg, July 1, 1863." typescript
"The Great Rebellion, A History of the 17th Connecticut Volunteer Infantry from 1862-1866," five volumes

arrangement.p: Bound randomly, photographs have identifications on verso, and some may duplicate loose photographs.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook, clippings regarding the 17th Connecticut Volunteers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Civil War manuscripts, consists of small collections of a few items, including not only correspondence, diaries, documents, photographs, and newspapers, but also ephemera, such as poems, patriotic song lyrics, ration slips, flags, and related items. Engravings of members of President Lincoln's Cabinet are included in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged alphabetically be personal name, family name, or subject.

did.unittitle: Brockway, C. B. correspondence from, to E. H. Little

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence (22 items) received by Burnham, a cotton manufacturer and Sunday School teacher from Uncasvile, Connecticut, from several of his former students regarding their activities as soldiers in the Federal Army during the Civil War in Virginia, South Carolina, and Florida. Correspondents include Henry T. Phillips (Lieutenant, 21st Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers), George R. Sanders (a negro hospital attendent, 3rd Regiment, Corps d'Afrique), Frederick E. Shalk (Sergeant, Co. E, 14th Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers), Edward Sharp (Private, Co. H, 7th Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers), John E. Sisson (Co. B, 3rd Brigade, 6th Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers), and David Sanders (Private, Co. H, 7th Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lyrics for a patriotic song in a program of graduation exercises for an unidentified school during the Civil War period. Includes lyrics for additional patriotic songs and poems, "Columbia, the Land of the Brave" and "Ellsworth's Avengers."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poems about the war with crayon drawings bound in.

did.unittitle: Cooke, Giles B. (Major, Confederate States of America)
Delaware Infantry. 2nd Regiment, payroll and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Of the 62 items in this collection, 52 are letters from three brothers, Henry B. Gill, George T. Gill, and William H. Gill, written while serving in the Union Army to their brother, John T. Gill, a dealer in flour and produce in New Haven. There are also a few letters to other members of the family, and some correspondence and documents from others relating to the war. The letters, sent from camps in Virginia, North Carolina, and Florida, discuss camp life, troop movements, the course of the war, provisions for the troops, and the private arrangements for trade made by the brothers who imported goods for resale from New Haven. There are also some fragments of poetry, possibly written by John T. Gill

did.unittitle: Gilman, Charles O., power of attorney to vote

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and a three pocket diary, 7th Regiment Connecticut Volunteers.

did.unittitle: Grosvenor, Samuel E., photocopies of 1864 diary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Hubbard was a physician and a commissioned surgeon of the 17th Regiment of the Connecticut Infantry (Volunteers) in 1862. The letters are almost all to his wife in Bridgeport, Connecticut, and describe his daily life, comments on the political situation, and on the progress of the war. Of particular interest are his full accounts of the battles of Gettysburg (1863 Jul 1-3), Lookout Mountain (1863 Nov 24), Missionary Ridge (1863 Nov 25), and Ringgold (1863 Nov 27) in which he was active as surgeon to the troops. With the letters are also obituaries and biographical information.

did.unittitle: Jacoby, W. H. correspondence from, to E. H. Little

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 22 letters in this collection are either by or to members of a family from Milford, Connecticut. A. P. Baldwin and his wife, Annie, live in New York City where they have a store, and their nine letters are addressed to his mother, Mrs. D. L. Baldwin, and his sister, Lotte [i.e. Charlotte A.] in Milford. Their letters, beginning on April 22, 1861, describe the events in New York City following the news of the firing on Fort Sumter, with reports on the sermons they heard on the following Sunday. The correspondence between the women includes family news and domestic arrangements. There is also a group of ten letters written by Lewis Nettleton to Lotte [his fiancée?] reporting the life of the ordinary soldier and commenting on the events of the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lovell F. Willard was born October 6, 1832, at Wardsboro, Vermont. His father was Eli Willard, born at Wardsboro, Vermont, October 2, 1783, and died August 3, 1864. His mother was Lucy Frost who was born November 17, 1787, and died August 24, 1846. Eli and Lucy were married at Townshend, Vermont, January 31, 1810.

Lovell Willard married Jane Deborah White Hobart on July 12, 1854. She was born March 30, 1834. Lovell died January 10, 1864, at Horican, Wisconsin, after contracting smallpox from a vaccination. They had five children. Lucy Augusta, born May 2, 1855, died March 13, 1935; Henrietta Lydia (or Lydiann), born November 7, 1856, died November 11, 1942; Jane Deborah, born March 28, 1859, died January 14, 1893; Sylvia Elizabeth, born July 12, 1861, died June 14, 1885; Lovella Flora, born May 9, 1863, died May 16, 1938.

Lucy married James Clifton Hall (January 21, 1851-April 17, 1906) on April 30, 1874. They had five children. The youngest was Hattie Marie born October 5, 1887, in Cherokee, Iowa. She died September 24, 1950, at Salem, South Dakota. She married Alexander Boyd Knox II January 3, 1912. They had four children. Alexander Boyd born April 6, 1913; Cather(ine) Jean born November 15, 1916, died November 25, 1978; Harriet Marie, born July 28, 1919; and Mary Alice born October 30, 1920. She, Mary Alice Albertson, is the donor of the diary of 1st Lieutenant Lovell F. Willard who served with Company "C" of the 29th Regiment of Wisconsin volunteers.
